metadata.title: Phantom Limb Pain
anatomical location body part affected: Upper and lower extremities, somatosensory and motor cortex of brain, spinal and peripheral nervous pathways
description: Phantom limb pain is the continued perception of pain from an amputated limb. Continued perception of sensation is experienced by most amputees; however, the perception of pain (i.e., phantom limb pain) is distinguished from phantom limb sensation
Phantom limb sensation is the perception of pain in a limb that no longer exists(17)

Phantom limb pain can be described as having a painful sensation associated with the missing body part.(1)It typically begins within the first postsurgical week and then stabilizes after a few months. In some cases, it may not begin until several months or years following the amputation(1) –It can be classified as a type of neuropathic pain(17) –Pain may be reported as very intense pain and may occur as a result of an external or internal stimulus(1) –Pain may also be reported as dull, continuous aching or burning that is not episodic(1)

Stump pain is pain arising from the residual part of the body as opposed to phantom pain, which is felt in the missing part of the body(1) –Stump pain is described as a sharp or sticking sensation or increased pressure that is localized to the end of the stump(1) –The most common cause of stump pain is prosthogenic, with neurogenic pain the second most common cause. Neurogenic pain results from the formation of a neuroma where the nerve was cut during amputation(1)

ICD-10 codes.G54.6: phantom limb syndrome with pain (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The occurrence of phantom limb pain in individuals who undergo amputation is reported to be as high as 80%.(1)Phantom pain is more common in traumatic amputation in adulthood and adolescence(2)
Typically, the onset of phantom limb pain is during the first week after surgical amputation; the pain generally wanes after several months. However, phantom limb pain may persist for years(1)

The patient may report the following painful sensations, distal to the level of the amputation in the extremity (e.g., below-knee  amputation and pain is perceived to be in the foot) –Profound burning(3) –Cramping(3) –Shooting(3) –Throbbing(1) –Squeezing(1) –Knife-like(1)

The focus of this Clinical Review is phantom limb pain; for more information on lower extremity amputation, please see Clinical Review…Amputation, Lower Extremity: Physical Therapy ; Item Number: T708442. For more information on upper extremity amputation, please see Clinical Review…Amputation, Upper Extremity, in Adults: Physical Therapy ; Item Number: T708916 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: There is no evidence in the literature that phantom pain is caused by psychological disorders, although stress andpsychological disturbances can exacerbate the pain(1)

Phantom pain is considered to be neuropathic pain (i.e., pain caused by dysfunction of the nervous system).(4) Neuropathicpain occurs when trauma results in secondary injury to a portion of the nervous system,(4) causing abnormal activation ofpain pathways. The damage can occur in the peripheral and/or central nervous system
Various factors generally present following an amputation are theorized to play a role, including the following:(3)–Irritation of the peripheral nerves–Atypical sympathetic nervous system functioning
The CNS is thought to be altered by amputation through the abrupt cessation of afferent nerve impulses(5)
pathogenesis: Complex changes take place throughout the body following amputation; the trauma to the peripheral nerves duringamputation sets off cellular alterations as well as structural alterations in the peripheral and central nervous systems. Forexample, chemicals/enzymes expelled when injury occurs come into contact with nociceptors for extended periods, leadingto hypersensitivity of these nociceptors(17)

Phantom limb pain may be associated with changes that take place after the nerve is completely cut. The nerves becomemore active and sensitive to chemical and mechanical changes, which can lead to an increased sensitivity to allodynia andhyperalgesia(17)
risk factors: Amputation–Most common with lower and upper extremities but can also occur with amputation or surgical removal of other bodyparts (e.g., breast, penis, eye, tongue)(6)–Eighty percent of patients with amputations experience some phantom pain at some point during the recovery process(1)
Stump pain – patients who complain of stump pain more frequently complain of phantom pain as well(6)

overall contraindications precautions: Carefully follow the surgeon’s orders and restrictions
The patient’s and family’s emotional state must be taken into account during evaluation and subsequent treatment

Following amputation, skin breakdown may result (e.g., from prosthetic use);(7) the clinician is advised to follow universal precautions and ensure that medical staff are aware of the compromised tissue
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the amputation? What was the cause? Document type of amputation and any postsurgical complications. If traumatic, were there any additional injuries? When did the phantom limb pain begin? Was there limb pain prior to or at the time of the amputation?

course of treatment.medical management: Regional anesthesia with local anesthetics may be tried. Surgery may include spinal cord stimulation electrode implantation, dorsal root ablation, or sympathectomy, in cases of intractable pain(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Phantom limb pain is usually diagnosed based on history and physical examination
Plain X-rays  and ultrasound may be used to diagnose underlying conditions
MRI, electrodiagnostic tests, or laboratory tests may be performed if other diagnoses are suspected(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, relaxation techniques, hypnosis, distraction, massage) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful (e.g., use of prosthetics)

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Aggravating factors may include -stress and anxiety(2,3) -shifts in weather patterns(19) -prosthetic use(2) -external stressors(19) -muscle tension(2) -Phantom limb pain is not relieved with change of position(2)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms, as applicable. Phantom limb pain is usually localized in distal parts of the absent limb, usually the hand or foot(2)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, throbbing, aching, burning, numbness, tingling, squeezing, pinching, or cramping). Episodic painful shocks may be described. Phantom limb pain is usually intermittent, although some patients have exacerbations superimposed on constant pain.(2) Inquire about other phantom sensations that may be annoying but not necessarily painful, including itching, pressure, touch, and movement
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. The pattern of symptoms may help differentiate central neuropathic pain from peripheral neuropathic pain. Peripheral nerve pain is more intense at night(8)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disorders are a common complication of phantom limb pain. Document number of wakings/ night
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., increase in pain, increased swelling in the residual limb). Increased anxiety and emotional arousal may be symptoms of PTSD and patient should be referred to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any respiratory compromise (e.g., need for supplemental oxygen) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of dysfunction in that limb? History of previous surgeries (e.g., bypass)?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently working? Has there been a loss of employment as a direct consequence of the amputation? Does the patient participate in any recreational activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any reported impairments in ADLs related to amputation and phantom limb pain
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  For comprehensive assessment procedures specific to upper or lower extremity amputation, see the appropriate Clinical Review. The areas listed below focus on the assessment of an individual with (or suspected of having) phantom limb pain
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Circumferential measurements may be used to monitor edema; compare to the unaffected limb. Measure residual limb length
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –As indicated, assess if assistive/adaptive and ambulatory devices are appropriate for the patient –Does the patient have a prosthesis? If so, is the fit appropriate and is the device well tolerated? If the patient does not have a prosthesis, is he or she a candidate, and has any prosthesis training occurred?
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Evaluate bilateral distal pulses; note general temperature of extremityComplete a functional assessment; document if pain increases during any particular activity. Use the FIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess patient’s gait with the use of any assistive devices and use of prosthesis, if available. Note any gait asymmetries or gait deviationsIs there any laxity noted in joints proximal to the amputation? Any joint restrictions? Use Paris Stoddard Scale for joint mobility assessmentAssess bilateral upper and lower extremities for abnormal tone or spasticity as indicated. Use the Modified Ashworth Scale to assess tone
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremity strength using manual muscle testing (MMT); include the residual limb, nonaffected extremities, and trunk
observation inspection palpation includi: Observe for skin breakdown elsewhere and improper fit of prosthesis
Examine and palpate residual limb for neuromas, cysts, bursae, bone spurs
relevant tests and measures.posture: Complete a full postural assessment, including standing with prosthesis; note deviations, in particular any that may be compensation due to pain
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Complete a full bilateral upper and lower extremity ROM assessment. Assess bilateral lower extremity flexibility. Use goniometryComplete an ADL assessment as indicated and document pain level during the various activities. Use Barthel Index or other standardized measure
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Tinel’s sign may be used to assist in differentiating neuroma pain from phantom limb pain(20) –Quality of life indices – phantom limb pain has been reported to be an important factor in determining quality of life post amputation. Use of a structured health-related  quality of life questionnaire, such as the WHO Quality of Life-BREF  or the Short Form Health Survey (SF-36),  may be indicated
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess cognition as indicated. Is patient alert and oriented x 4?

contraindications precautions: Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of DVT or thrombophlebitis
Individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including those in regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients with chronic neuropathic pain often require management with many medications and adjunctive therapies, and are at risk for drug addiction(9)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(10)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The presence of phantom limb pain is an indication for physical/occupational therapy
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Chronic postsurgical pain(2) Neuralgia(2) Angina(2) DVT or pain that is vascular in origin
prognosis: Phantom pain typically decreases in frequency, duration, and severity over the course of 6 months after amputation(1)

Phantom limb pain that is still present 6 months after amputation is difficult to treat and usually does not respond to standard treatment options(1) ›Referral to other disciplines  (as appropriate and indicated)
other considerations: Spinal cord stimulation may be effective in reducing phantom limb pain –Epidural electrodes are permanently implanted after a trial of percutaneous stimulation successfully reduces pain

Transcranial direct current stimulation over the motor cortex (superficially) may be effective for management of post-amputation  phantom limb pain(12) –Based on a crossover, double-blind,  sham-controlled  study in Italy –Eight subjects with unilateral lower or upper limb amputation and chronic phantom limb pain were included –Nodal transcranial direct current stimulation was applied over the motor cortex at 1.5 mA for 15 minutes. Patients received 5 consecutive days of treatment (active or sham) –Response to active treatment was immediate phantom limb pain relief and increased ability to move phantom limb; improvements lasted for 1 week after treatment concluded. Response to sham treatment was variable, with patients noting an increase or decrease in symptoms from baseline
Acupuncture or hypnosis may be tried(3)

Authors of a study in the United Kingdom of 75 military personnel who had unilateral or bilateral lower extremity amputations concluded that 56% of the participants experienced a change in the severity of phantom limb pain with visceral stimuli (bowel or bladder filling or evacuating)(14)
Virtual-reality  rehabilitation can be effective at treating phantom limb pain associated with phantom limb movement (i.e., clamping, gnawing)(15)
treatment summary: Authors of an RCT study have suggested that mirror therapy treatment can reduce the intensity, duration, and frequency of phantom limb pain, with improvements being maintained for up to 12 weeks post therapy(16) –Sixty patients with amputation and phantom limb pain were randomized to either the experimental group (n = 32) or control group (n = 28) –The experimental group completed 4 weeks of mirror therapy and were followed up 12 weeks after completion  –Sessions were 15 minutes daily for 4 weeks

Mirror visual feedback (MVF) is a treatment intervention in which movement of one limb is perceived as movement of the other limb using visual feedback with a mirror. MVF may alleviate phantom limb pain(11,13) –According to a 2015 systematic review, mirror therapy is a promising and low-cost  treatment for phantom limb pain(13) -One hundred thirty-seven  articles were reviewed and 7 were included in the review -Due to the heterogeneity of the literature, additional larger RCTs are warranted . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Phantom limb pain Reduce phantom limb pain to improve ability to complete ADLs, tolerate prosthesis, and participate in rehabilitation programTherapeutic interventions _ Other interventions may include ultrasound,(5) thermotherapy,(5) vibration,(5) and massage(5,7) _ _

decreased pain and normalized sensation: Improved performance of ADLs, use of prosthesis, and participation in rehabilitation program–FIM, Barthel Index, gait/prosthetic assessment
Improved psychosocial well-being–TAPES-R,  quality of life indices (WHO Quality of Life-BREF  or SF-36)

maintenance or prevention: Maintenance: Patients with phantom limb pain should adhere to their home program to maintain achieved pain relief. Daily residual limb inspection should also be completed (this is especially important in prosthetic users)
